title: Filipino Lumpia Recipe
description: Serve these delicious lumpia on special occasions. You'll find lumpia wrappers in Asian markets or substitute eggroll wrappers. Serve with banana ketchup.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Global Cuisines Asian Filipino Filipino Lumpia 4.3 (43) 39 Reviews 6 Photos My Filipino stepmother made these delicious lumpia on special occasions. You can find frozen lumpia wrappers at Asian grocery stores or use egg roll wrappers as a substitute. Serve with banana ketchup if you can find it. Submitted by Jen Updated on September 7, 2024 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 6 6 6 6 Prep Time: 1 hr Cook Time: 10 mins Total Time: 1 hr 10 mins Servings: 6 Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 6 servings 1 (12 ounce) package lumpia wrappers 1 pound ground beef ½ pound ground pork ⅓ cup finely chopped onion ⅓ cup finely chopped green bell pepper ⅓ cup finely chopped carrot 1 quart oil for frying Directions Thaw lumpia wrappers if frozen. Lay several wrappers on a clean, dry surface and cover with a damp towel to prevent wrappers from drying out. Mix beef, pork, onion, green pepper, and carrot together in a medium bowl. Place about 2 tablespoons of meat mixture along center of wrapper. Do not overstuff wrappers or they will burn before meat is cooked. Fold one edge of wrapper over filling. Fold outer edges in slightly, then roll into a closed cylinder. Wet finger with water and moisten outer edge to seal. Repeat with remaining wrappers and filling, keeping finished lumpia covered to prevent drying. Heat oil in a 9-inch skillet on medium to medium-high heat until oil reaches 365 to 375 degrees F (170 to 175 degrees C). Fry 3 to 4 lumpia at a time, turning in oil until nicely browned, about 2 to 3 minutes per side. Drain on paper towels. Cut each lumpia into thirds for parties, and serve with banana ketchup, if you like. Editor's Note We have determined the nutritional value of oil for frying based on a retention value of 10% after cooking. The exact amount may vary depending on cook time and temperature, ingredient density, and the specific type of oil used. I Made It Print 66 home cooks made it! Add Your Photo Photos of Filipino Lumpia 01 of 06 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 02 of 06 Photo by  Ms. Mercado 09/05/2016 my boyz loved this Lumpias. Def making them again. 03 of 06 Photo by  LatinaCook 05/16/2012 I like to use all pork and sometimes add chopped cooked shrimp at the end. I also like to season the mixture with salt, pepper, garlic powder and a bit of soy sauce. Shredded cabbage is good in this as well as chopped scallions. To dip, I like to make a sauce of equal parts brown sugar and water boiled down with a bit of cornstarch to thicken and then seasoned with garlic powder and red pepper flakes. 04 of 06 Photo by  LatinaCook 05/16/2012 I like to use all pork and sometimes add chopped cooked shrimp at the end. I also like to season the mixture with salt, pepper, garlic powder and a bit of soy sauce. Shredded cabbage is good in this as well as chopped scallions. To dip, I like to make a sauce of equal parts brown sugar and water boiled down with a bit of cornstarch to thicken and then seasoned with garlic powder and red pepper flakes. 05 of 06 Photo by  LatinaCook 05/16/2012 I like to use all pork and sometimes add chopped cooked shrimp at the end. I also like to season the mixture with salt, pepper, garlic powder and a bit of soy sauce. Shredded cabbage is good in this as well as chopped scallions. To dip, I like to make a sauce of equal parts brown sugar and water boiled down with a bit of cornstarch to thicken and then seasoned with garlic powder and red pepper flakes. 1 You’ll Also Love Bopis Recipe 4 Ratings Pinakbet 26 Ratings Crab Omelet 6 Ratings Filipino Fish Escabeche 3 Ratings Sinigang na Bangus (Filipino Milkfish in Tamarind Broth) 1 Rating Original Steak Tartare 16 Ratings Cantonese Style Pork and Shrimp Dumplings 25 Ratings Clams in Oyster Sauce 5 Ratings Pressure Cooker Carnitas 127 Ratings Lumpia in the Air Fryer 7 Ratings Spring Rolls 49 Ratings Cindi's Egg Rolls 104 Ratings Cuban Shredded Pork 109 Ratings Pork for Tamales 16 Ratings Chinese Style Stuffed Mushrooms 6 Ratings Pork in Olive Oil Marinade 36 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: Jen
instructions: Thaw lumpia wrappers if frozen. Lay several wrappers on a clean, dry surface and cover with a damp towel to prevent wrappers from drying out.;Mix beef, pork, onion, green pepper, and carrot together in a medium bowl. Place about 2 tablespoons of meat mixture along center of wrapper. Do not overstuff wrappers or they will burn before meat is cooked. Fold one edge of wrapper over filling. Fold outer edges in slightly, then roll into a closed cylinder. Wet finger with water and moisten outer edge to seal. Repeat with remaining wrappers and filling, keeping finished lumpia covered to prevent drying.;Heat oil in a 9-inch skillet on medium to medium-high heat until oil reaches 365 to 375 degrees F (170 to 175 degrees C). Fry 3 to 4 lumpia at a time, turning in oil until nicely browned, about 2 to 3 minutes per side. Drain on paper towels.;Cut each lumpia into thirds for parties, and serve with banana ketchup, if you like.
